Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 06:13PM Sue-Ann wrote: I'm here too.  I've been trying to start radiation for the past three weeks, but am still too swollen.  I had another ct scan last week and they'll check me again next Wednesday.  I just want to get things going.
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 10:22PM - edited Feb 2, 2009 10:23PM by Sue-Ann Hello all.  Thanks for bringing up the issue of the shorter Canadian rad treatments vs. the US treatments.  I'm being treated in Berkeley, CA and my team informed me about the Canadian study, but recommended I follow the typical 5-6 week treatment.  I still haven't started treatment and am meeting with the rad group on Wednesday and will pose the question again.  Also, would love comments on the set up for the treatment.  They have me on my back with my breast basically under my armpit.  It just makes more sense to me to have me face down similar to the biopsy they did.  It just seems to me they would zap less lung tissue that way.?.   Lori, I watched the NBC segment and they seem to have justification for a shorter term plan and the video looked like it shows the woman laying face down for her treatment. Help me out girls, cause the way I'm getting set up seems a little strange to me.   Thanks,  Sue
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 11:37PM Sue-Ann wrote: Thanks Lori for the additional information.  I'll be ready to discuss my concerns with them again on Wednesday. I'll let everyone know how it goes.  S
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 12:06PM Sue-Ann wrote: Hello to all.....  I started my first treatment today.  It went okay.  I was nervous, but it all seemed to happen like no big deal.  Thanks Mary for the idea of counting.  Right when I was getting scared, I started to count and it was all over before I reached 100.  One down, 35 to go. Mandy, I have had several photos taken.  I tend to be on the private side as well.  What I've noticed is there are quite a few technicians that rotate through the set-up and treatments.  And today, my first day of radiation, I had two technicians that I hadn't seen before.  My file was open and I watched them refer to the photos (especially when they were checking the plaster cast template to see if I had any changes to my breast since the set up last week and yesterday). I actually found comfort in them being so precise and making sure everything was lining up.   I hope telling you about my experience may have helped.   I hope your treatment today goes easily. Sincerely,  Sue
Posts.Title: February 2009 rads group - all aboard!! Lories sobx

Posts.Content: Sue-Ann wrote: Okay folks, here's my story to share....   Diagnosed with DCIS (> 7cm) in November. 1st surgery I bled in recovery.  They bound me and got it stopped.  Didn't get clean margins so back to the OR.  This time my surgeon was ready for the bleeding and used FloSeal (By Baxter).  Yea, no bleeding this time and clean margins.  Skip ahead 6 months later to my follow-up Mammogram.  I now have microcalcifications throughout my scar tissue and everyone is scratching their heads wondering why it's there.  I'm devastated, exhausted, mad....   Then, my friend finds this recently published article about how FloSeal should not be used for bleeding control in breast tissue because it creates mircocalcifications!  I still have to go through another stereotactic biopsy this week to confirm the findings, but at least I have hope that there is a reason this time for the alarming mamo.  Please read the article and if you are prone to bleeding make sure your surgeon knows not to use this product. (Because they don't all have this new information.)   http://breast-imaging.blogspot.com/2009/04/surgical-gel-used-to-stop-bleeding.html  Dx 11/18/2008, DCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, Grade 2, 0/0 nodes Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgical Gel Used To Stop Bleeding Could Confuse Mammograms Sue-Ann Sue-Ann
